WRITING.TEXT:
As /u/Aiyon pointed out in another answer the code is not something that is special to Dan, everybody can get a referral link with a kickback. Beside he is not hiding that he has an affiliate link from Lootcrate, because it's easy to see. Also I don't think he makes the videos because of the link, but because he likes the idea or whatever.
For the Plants vs. Zombies video: It was a "Tests" video meaning he does not freaking research the video. He states so himself in the video. He test a game and gives his impressions for the first time playing it.
He's not even half as professional as he claims to be.
Please point me to an statement of Dan where claims to be professional. As far as I know he does YouTube because he has fun with it and makes a bit of money. From my knowledge he never claimed that he is professional or unbiased at all. All I know is that he said that he will never do a video about a game if a company aproaches him with a sponsorship (that's at least what I understood).
All in all I think you makeing a big fuss about nothing at all.

And he is not claiming that in the article, not in one word. He is saying that though donating it, they most likely have to pay less taxes thus the government has less money. That is what he is saying. He does not claim anywhere, that they are doing it to "doge taxes"

He is not saying that they do it to doge taxes, but that in the US you can write off donations from the taxes. Let's say someone would normally pay $200,000 in taxes and write off $100,000 because of donations, that means that the government gets only half of what it normally would. He is not saying what they are doing is per se bad, but that the way they are doing it and asking others to do it may actually not be the best way to do it.

I would argue that both applies to this. ISA is both obsolete and deprecated. It's deprecated because it was superseded by PCI, but it's obsolete, because the benefits of using PCI were higher than the inconvinece of using ISA.
I would go for obsoleted, but that's only because I never heard deprecated outside of software.

It's kind of complicated as far as I know. If the BGH, the highest court in Germany (except when in matters of constituional law [or whatever it's called in English]), declares that an decision would always be the same, it's for the most part safe to assume that the decision will be same. However it does not have the same binding as a law for lower instances, also the BGH can change what the statue is.
Also publisher would not have to take it to law, they just would have to try to publish a game containing the symbols and then get to court if they have to change it. So when the game get's through and nobody complains about it, not lawsuit no costs.
Thing is unless one or more publisher at least try to get games recognized as art it won't change. It's kind of a typical chicken and egg problem, as long as there is no case where a game got through with it, no publisher will try it, but as long as no publisher tries it.
That still does not make it part of the constitution.
You can convert a scaled vector graphic to a bitmap graphic, but not the over way around afaik

No seriously who are you to judge about the laws in a different country? There are stupid laws I grant you that, but whether the laws in question are ridiculous or not, is not up to you to decide.
I'm German and I honestly don't have a problem with them. They sometimes impact my life, but most of the time I couldn't care less. I don't blame the law though, because video game publishers could fight for the "right" to display the symbols. Their work just needs to be recognized as art.

13 hour delays are not even a thing in the Netherlands.
Because with a 13 hour delay the train would need to be in France or something.

One thing:
It's **not** and **never** was part of the constition. The law(s) in question are 86 StGB and 86a StGB. They are not part of our constitution. The "Grundgesetzt" is our constitution.
You mean like the right to have weapons in case the British attack?

Just a little correction (?), the politics are not alone to blame. Any publisher would've the right to take it to a court to get a ruling if his usage of the swastika can be considered art. One such ruling may help others to get a simmilar result.
In the law in questions movies and other things are not mentioned directly, so it is a question for a court if the law applies to a spezific work or not.
Thing is though, if a publisher would try to get his game considered as art he would have a chance to win a the lawsuite. After that every other publisher could point to that court ruling.

It is **not** part of our constitution, but our constitution allows such a law. The law in question in 82 StGB and 82a StGB (and in case of the Nazi Salut 130 StGB). Please inform yourself, before you spread misinformation.

Johnny would get punished for that if he does not give space to an lapping car if there is space. Also most drivers wouldn't want to interfere if possible, because of the shit they would get afterwards not only from the driver but also from press and fans.

race control then lets the drivers that have been lapped, overtake the rest of the cars and drive at racing speed until they reach the back of the safety car pack
Not compeltley true, on longer tracks they just have to travel a certain distance.
My question is, with all of Formula 1's technology and all the very intelligent people who work in the sport, why the fuck can't they just have the cars drop to the back of the pack and then subtract a lap from their total?
Tyre wear and fuel for the most part. It gives the lapped cars an unfair benefit to the cars right in front of them.
There people pushing for video evidence in football (soccer). But as ever UEFA and FIFA are against it. Afaik the FIFA more then the UEFA.
Yes and no. It's harder to score an away goal thus it is somehow more "worth", but it's just weird if a team just gets to the next round because they only lost 0:1 at home and won 1:2 at the enemy.

According to **part** of my definition of an RPG. Never claimed that the above is the whole definiton.
Did I ever claim that any of the games you picked were an RPG? Please show it to me where I actually claimed that The Walking Dead is an RPG and I mean actually claiming not you impling on one statement from me that I would do so.
Okay, let's pick a Bioware game as you seem to think highly of them. Mass Effect, without question it is an RPG right? Does it let you play as a bad guy? Sort of, but not really. It gives you the illusion that you are the bad guy, but in the end you are still the freaking hero if you want it or not. You save many people and systems, so you are not a bad guy, you are just not as good as you can be. Alas D D does not count, this discussion is about videogames and D D is not a video game, heck D D is not game in itself, D D is a system.
There is no choice in any videogame up so far, all you have is more or less the illusion of choice. I honestly don't know any RPG that has not a limited amount of endings and thus limits your choices throughout the game. The limit may be higher for some and lower for others, but it does not change the fact that they are limiedt. So a game as Fallout 4, which sparked this whole debate, limits you in some ways more than a Mass Effect or Fable, but still it's a freaking RPG.
Last but not least I want to quote the Wikipedia article on RPG, maybe not the best source, but there is no formal definition of RPG.
A role-playing game (RPG and sometimes roleplaying game) is a game in which players **assume the roles of characters in a fictional setting**. Players take responsibility for **acting out these roles within a narrative**, either through literal acting or through a process of structured decision-making or character development.
Emphasis by me.
Never said that the story defines an RPG. There is more to any game then the story. Heck the story does not define a genre at all.

Would you consider "The Secret of Monkey Island" an RPG?
No, but because it lacks other things that define an RPG. An RPG for me contains kind of a leveling and gear system. Neither of which is found in the Point and Click Adventure you mentioned.
How much freedom do you really have if the story is nigh linear?
The story is not the only thing defining what an RPG is. An RPG is more than the story and frankly a story with much freedom may not belong to an RPG and vice-versa.
Where would you draw the line?
I would decide from case to case, because there is no clear drawn border, as there is with no genre. Frankly speaking to a degree this thinking in genres is kind of stupid nowadays, because there are so many games that bastards between two or more genres.

As a German I can not attest to this statement. There are great restaurants and food shacks in Germany and there are bad ones. German cuisine for the most part is yummy and fills one up (I don't mean beer guys!).

Actually I think many people are mistaken about what an RPG is. An RPG does not have to give the player 100% freedom. An RGP is about playing the role of a character. This also means that the character in a game is a good guy, you as a player should not have the freedom to play him as a bad guy. It's not what the character is.
And even through in Fallout 4 you can kind of create your own character, your character is to a degree predefined. It's not an empty paper, (s)he has lived years before the war and (s)he has a kid, those are things that define someone as a person.
Not every taxi drivers are that way. In fact most of them are not that way, but as always a few bad apples spoil the basket.
Never expect consistence from people. They are inheriently inconsistent. But yeah you are right and just gave a great example of what I mean.

Actually I think most people talking about this are mistaking novelty for creatively. Even a game like CoD or yes an NFL needs a certain amount of creativity. It's not the same creativity as you may find in a Child of Light and it certainly is not novel, but still.
Also often times those people forget that the publishers and the studios are freaking businesses. I would wager that many and more people working at EA or Ubisoft would like to put up a great novel game with the budget of the latest AC or BF game, but from a business standpoint such a risk may not be worth it. Instead they opt for the "boring" non novel approach, but are making a profit with that.
Another thing is, that the people who are complaining are most likely the minority. Many and more people are okay with how the CoD franchise is the "same" in the last few iterations.

Then the cell is not correctly formatted. If you format the cell correctly it does not matter in what locale you create or change it, the display value is generated depending on the locale of the system displaying it.
So if you have a cell with the value 1.5 with a French locale it would display 1,5 with English locale it displays as 1.5. Same goes for every cell format.
In Germany it depends on many things. IANAL but I think after you turn 14 or 16 you can either be tried as a child or an adult.
Well it's the official statement of a Valve developer found [here](http://dev.dota2.com/showthread.php?t=63789).

WRITING.TITLE: Should I go out or play FO4?
WRITING.TEXT:
Basicly the title, but I want to give a bit of perspective.
I had the last week free and already booked about 40hrs into Fallout 4. I still haven't seen everything or even done everything I want to in this playthough...But it's Saturday night where I'm located and I could go out to have a bit of social fun.
Also I'm 25/m and I would go alone.

You can't give away single games. The whole anthology is one Steam code. Also while the nuke looks good, it feels cheap.
Source: I have it.

I don't see a foul, it was clearly on the border between foul and clean play, but for me it does not look like a foul. The thing is all we have to go from is this honestly kind of shitty gif. The ref is right in front of it and had the better view.
Even if the ref has made a bad call, the reaction of the player was unsportman like and he should be banned from EVER playing again. People like that should not be playin any shlightly competive sport or game.

I think the ball was outside of the field. And the time you are down and obscuring is irrelevant, there are situations where a ref may not directly call it, but here for me it looked like he did it on purpose.

Actually he was staggering at the begining and then was upright again when the first in blue made physical contact with him, which throw him off balance again. He then shielded the ball from the defenders. The first one wanted to make space in the moment the attacker stood up, which caused him to fall over again. The second defender did not touch him I think.
All in all the player in yellow was in the wrong the call of the ref was right.

During matches streams should turn off player names entirely and only use the names of the heroes instead.
No, there may be people watching who don't know every hero by name, for them it would be impossible to follow it.
The solution is as simple as not allowing the players to change their names while participating in a tournament begining at the qualifier. They can change the name in non official matches but in the official ones they are required to use the ingame name with which they are registered to the tournament.
Player names are an unnecessary piece of visual clutter on the stream and useless info in the audio.
Nope, same as in "real" sports the name is a way to identify a person. If you were just to watch the stream on the side without names it would be harder to follow if you can't remember which player got which hero or even worse if you tuned in later.
They confuse any spectators who don't follow the scene closely.
I don't follow the scene cloesly anymore and I don't have any problems when I watch a game. Same goes for any other sport I may watch. If I have a name to associate with something (e.g. jersey number or hero) I know who the commentators are talking about.
Fans who care already know which players on the teams play each role, so they don't need to hear the names over and over.
They don't need to, but it makes it easier.,
Have you proof that the engine is to 100% the same? I'm not saying it's a complete new engine but an iteration. They patched and maybe changed things while keeping much of it the same.

Using a ten year old engine is honestly unacceptable in a AAA game in this day and age.
No, it isn't. Most game engines are just iterations of older engines and I'm sure that the eninge used for Fallout 4 is different to the one used in Sykrim, while sharing the same code to a degree. It's a common theme amonst most parts of development, to reuse as much code as you can. The longer you use code the more bugs you may be able to find and fix.
The time and cost would not have mattered at all if it had made people shit their pants with how amazing it was.
It would've Bethesda is a fucking company not somekind of non profit organization. People have to understand, that game development is business and every decision has to be made with the business in mind. Beside a new engine would introduce a metric ton of new bugs that people would complain about.
As it stands, all the bugs and relatively poor graphics have brought the Metacritic user score almost 5 full points below the critic score.
Metacritic is not a score I would allow in an argument. It's bullshit and it's easy to forge. Also the graphics are not "relativley poor" they hold up to most games. Sure there are games with way better graphics, but they lack in other parts where Fallout 4 is better. Graphics is not everything and to be honest for me graphics are not as important as the gameplay.
I have a feeling there are a lot of people like me that are waiting to buy this game, not because it costs too much, but because we're waiting for the community patches that are required to fix Bethesda games.
Didn't need any community patches for Fallout 3 nor New Vegas nor Morrowind. Skyrim I didn't pick up right away, because I didn't feel like it. Maybe I'm just one of the lucky few who do not experience bugs as often or who are just playing to enjoy the game and thus "ignore" some flaws.
How much revenue is lost to people like me? Enough to fund a new engine, maybe?
No, most likely not. The costs for the eninge don't end when the game is released. For a new enigne they may have to release patches for it, because of bugs in the engine code. If you develop your own engine you will have running costs for the lifetime of it. You can't just develop it and then be done.

All I see is that the lips sometimes may not 100% match what is being said, however it does not bother me that much. And the other big animation thing reddit jerked about with the Vault-Tec guy at the start. Didn't see it, even when I tried to see it, no way of seeing it.
However I must say, that I play on PC with the locked FPS and am getting a constant 60. Maybe it has something to do with that.

That's really unfortunate. I played 27 hours and have yet to encounter any big bugs. I had one or two things spasm out after being hit by an explosion and the most annyoing bug I have encountered is when my PipBoy or my gun is not rendered in first person. When I switch to third person it's all there and I can use it like normal.
In my opinion while far from perfect Fallout 4 feels like one of the better triple-A launches in recent history. I can understand why some people may be dissapointed because they got hyped up way to much, but all in all it's a great game which I will be playing for a long time and even will fire up in a few years.
Not if he kept the statue, refund would only be possible with the complete product.

I don't think they really compete with each other, because in the origin they were aimed at different groups of people. I play both series, Settlers up until The Settlers IV and Anno I just didn't get the new one yet.
Anno for me always hat the more mature theme and you are focused on the grander theme of things. You don't have to give every little pathway it's own transportation dude or your wares will stack up. It happens automatic. Also in Settlers there is no statsifaction meter for your people, they are basicly a ressource.
In general for me The Settlers was always more about ressource and micro management, while Anno was more of a settlement simulation where you at one point start focus on building pretty.

No, the GEMA-Vermutung is a real thing. For example mentioned [here](http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Bundesregierung-steht-hinter-der-GEMA-Vermutung-1743629.html) or [here on Wikipedia](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/GEMA-freie_Musik#GEMA-Vermutung) read up on it. It's kind of sad, because it means that you are basicly guilty until proven otherwise.

Through some laws the GEMA is allowed to assume every artist is part of her unless the artist states otherwise. The basic reason behind it is not that bad if you think about it for a second. In the best case it would mean people who want to broadcast music publicy only need to pay the GEMA for the rights to broadcast the music. In practice however the GEMA wants to much and has huge problems.

First of english is not my first language so I may misuse a word or two, feel free to correct me.
I didn't cut myself for cutting myself. For me it started because I wanted to hurt myself for reasons, but I was to much of a wus to do any "real" harm. Then I noticed how the pain it created made all the emotional pain and turmoil feel mundane, it "helped" me cope with all the penned up anger, pain and turmoil in me. Then it started to escalate to the point where I was mere seconds from endig myself then and there. But something always got in "the way".
I'm not really cutting myself anymore, though I still hurt myself when I'm in emotional stress. Maybe I pound on the wall with my fist until it bleeds or I take a piece of metal and heat it up until it's glowing red and press it against my body or I bite my cheek until I taste the sweet blood of mine.
I know it's not healthy and I know I should seek help, but I'm getting by currently so I postpone it.

I'm a IT support and programmer in a small company. I make ~17 (~$19) an hour. I have social security becuase of the country I live in, but that means after everything is deducted I have roughly 10 (~$11) per hour left.
I like it here, my bosses are nice and appreciate me, they even gave me raise for my year working here. Normally I get 13 wages a year.

People not really understanding what the internet is. Or the balant lying. For example:
C: "I can't login" M: "Do you use your customer no. as username?" C: "Yeah..Oh now it works. Must have been a hickup in the system." M: "....Yeah, any other questions I can help with?"
Seriously, I can see that prior to the working log in that there were no failed attemps. And no our system worked like charm, because if not many other things would not have worked either...

Yes and no. We only have to types "Sie" and "Du". I think [this](http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/german-formal-or-informal-greetings.html) is a good little explanation.

Yes, we are taking refugees. I think it's the right thing to do, but by no means do I think the current situation is good in any way or form. Also I'm kind of pissed at the countries that won't take refugees.

Well the mandatory:
"Heil Hitler" or "Sieg Heil" maybe okay in one or more countries but in Germany you get in serious serious trouble. Not only is it offensive but it may also get you in legal trouble.
Again Germany: Using informal pronouns. We have a formal pronoun and in most professional situations you use that instead of the informal. It's not really offensive but very very rude.
